subject: Re: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
msgSnippet: Section 3.3 Reporting results- TestResult of JUnit A Cook s Tour gives a really good account of the design motivation for making test results the way they
messageBody:
Section 3.3 Reporting results- TestResult of "JUnit A Cook's Tour" gives a
really good account of the design motivation for making test results the way
they are-- (i guess it all boils down to simplicity :)

http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/cookstour/cookstour.htm

Levi

----- Original Message -----
From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, July 16, 2001 3:27 PM
Subject: RE: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?


> I agree with you. It's one of those things that may be nice, but it isn't
> necessary - and thus it shouldn't go into the base.
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: rainsber@... [mailto:rainsber@...]
> > Sent: Monday, July 16, 2001 6:23 PM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: Re: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
> >
> >
> > I re-read this and think I should follow up. By my second
> > sentence, I meant
> > that counting asserts is something that not everyone --
> > and perhaps not a
> > majority of people -- do. I didn't mean to imply that
> > because *I* didn't do
> > it, Erich and Kent didn't put it in the framework. I
> > don't know them that
> > well. :)
> >
> > J. B. Rainsberger <rainsber@...>
> > Commerce Suite Accelerator: Rule Services, IBM Toronto Lab
> > 8200 Warden Av, Office A3-735 [A3/FNB/8200/MKM]
> > Markham ON L6G 1C7
> > 905 413-2501 (969-2501)
> >
> >
> > Joe Rainsberger/Toronto/IBM@IBMCA on 07/16/2001 18:18:57
> >
> > Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com
> >
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > cc:
> > Subject: Re: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
> >
> >
> >
> > I've been working with JUnit for about a year now and I
> > never had the
> > desire to count "asserts". That might be the reason it's
> > not in the
> > framework. I, for one, hope it does not become part of
> > the framework.
> > Moreover, I have grave concerns that once JUnit goes
> > truly Open Source, it
> > will cease to be a lightweight, simple test framework.
> >
> > Thoughts?
> >
> > J. B. Rainsberger <rainsber@...>
> > Commerce Suite Accelerator: Rule Services, IBM Toronto Lab
> > 8200 Warden Av, Office A3-735 [A3/FNB/8200/MKM]
> > Markham ON L6G 1C7
> > 905 413-2501 (969-2501)
> >
> >
> > "Di Iorio, Matthew (ISS Atlanta)" <mdiiorio@...> on
> > 07/16/2001 18:10:39
> >
> > Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com
> >
> > To: "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> > cc:
> > Subject: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
> >
> >
> >
> > We've done the same with our JUnit. I've heard a few
> > other people on the
> > list mention modifying JUnit to count asserts. Is there
> > a good reason that
> > it isn't part of the framework? Since a few of us have
> > already done it,
> > I'm
> > sure we could make the change pretty easily.
> >
> > Matt
> >
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
> > Sent: Monday, July 16, 2001 10:40 AM
> > To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> > Subject: RE: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown
> > exception ?
> >
> >
> > We have modified JUnit to count asserts, because we find
> > that to be
> > interesting data for metrics. Therefore, since we are
> > implying that
> > something went wrong when it was supposed to, we do an
> > assert to add to the
> > count.
> >
> >
